intro: Ocimum ebracteatum, commonly known as the African basil, is a herbaceous plant native to tropical Africa. It is characterized by its aromatic leaves, which are often used in traditional medicine and culinary applications. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, lance-shaped leaves that are often hairy. Its flowers are small, tubular, and clustered in whorls, typically in shades of purple or white. Ocimum ebracteatum is a member of the Lamiaceae family, sharing characteristics with other basil species such as its square stems and aromatic oils.
